questions.text: What is the most common type of headache?
questions.solution:
The most common type of headache is tension-type headache (TTH).

The pain of TTH can generally be managed with simple analgesics such as acetaminophen, aspirin, or NSAIDs. For chronic TTH, amitriptyline is the only proven treatment.

Causes of primary headache, in decreasing order:  

  • Tension-type headache
  • Migraine
  • Idiopathic stabbing
  • Exertional 
  • Cluster

Causes of secondary headache, in decreasing order:

  • Systemic infection
  • Head injury 
  • Vascular disorders 
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Brain tumor

questions.text: What is the most common cause of secondary headache?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of secondary headache is a systemic infection.

Causes of primary headache, in decreasing order:  

  • Tension-type headache

  • Idiopathic stabbing
  • Exertional 
  • Cluster

questions.text: Which of the following case scenarios do not depict tension-type headache?

choices.text: A 34-year-old woman presenting with a chronic headache for >15 days per month
A 41-year-old man presenting with a  bilateral headache lasting for 4-6 hours
A 38-year-old man presenting with a  tight band-like discomfort around the head
A 34-year-old woman presenting with a pulsatile headache associated with nausea

questions.solution:
A pulsatile headache associated with nausea is not a feature of tension-type headache (TTH).

Tension-type headache is a chronic head-pain syndrome characterized by bilateral, tight, band-like discomfort. The pain typically builds slowly, fluctuates in severity, and may persist more or less continuously for many days. The headache may be episodic or chronic (present >15 days per month).

questions.text: A 41-year-old man has a 4-year history of severe left-sided excruciating episodic headaches. Most episodes are accompanied by ipsilateral lacrimation, conjunctival injection, and rhinorrhea. There are no cutaneous triggers. It does not respond to indomethacin and attacks get triggered by alcohol. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of cluster headache. Patients with cluster headaches are more often smokers with a higher than average alcohol consumption.

Cluster headache causes severe, unilateral periorbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. Occasionally features of Horner's syndrome may be seen. The pain, though severe, is characteristically brief (30–90 minutes). There are 1-8 attacks/day lasting for 15min-3 hours.

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicranias
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua

questions.text: A man presents with complaints of a recurrent left-sided stabbing headache. He has been experiencing this every day, along with a runny nose during the episodes, for the last week. These episodes last for about an hour. Examination shows the following. Which of the following is not used for the prophylaxis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Repetitive brief, unilateral, stabbing headaches associated with lacrimation and rhinorrhea suggest a diagnosis of cluster headaches. Indomethacin is not used for the prophylaxis of these headaches.

The drug of choice used in the prophylaxis of cluster headaches is verapamil. Steroids and lithium can also be used.

questions.text: What is the most common positive visual aura seen by patients during an attack of migraine?
questions.solution:
The most common positive visual aura seen in attacks of migraine is a zig-zag line in front of the eyes.

The most common negative visual aura is scotoma.

The classic migraine is associated with an aura. The aura can be:

  • Visual (most common):
    • Zigzag lines
    • Tunnel vision
    • Scotoma 
    • Transient visual loss 
  • Sensory:
    • Tingling sensation of hands, which spreads proximally

questions.text: A 26-year old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had similar episodes in the past where the headache usually lasts for 1-2 days. Bright light increases her discomfort and she prefers sitting in a dark room. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Multiple unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea, vomiting and photophobia suggests a diagnosis of migraine. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) is a vasoactive neuropeptide associated with this condition. It is present at vascular terminations of the trigeminal nerve and within the trigeminal nucleus.

CGRP antagonists approved for migraine prevention are:

  • Erenumab
  • Fremanezumab
  • Galcanezumab
  • Eptinezumab 

Note:

The FDA has recently approved Atogepant, a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in adults. The recommended dosage is 10 mg, 30 mg, or 60 mg orally once daily. In severe renal impairment or end-stage renal disease it is 10 mg once daily.

questions.text: In patients with familial hemiplegic migraine, which of the following is least likely to be defective?
questions.solution:
Familial hemiplegic migraine (FHM) is due to defective voltage-gated calcium channel gene, sodium-potassium ATPase gene, and voltage-gated sodium channel. The voltage-gated chloride channel is not defective in this condition.

 Type Mutation
 FHM 1 Voltage-gated calcium channel (CACNAIA)gene
 FHM 2 Sodium -potassium ATPase (ATPIA2) gene
 FHM 3 Voltage-gated sodium channel (SCNIA)

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman experiences severe throbbing headaches on the right side of her forehead. Soon after the headache begins, she becomes very nauseous and occasionally gets dizzy. She has also vomited multiple times during these episodes and is subsequently diagnosed with severe migraine. Which among the following is the most efficacious triptan used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The most efficacious triptans for moderate to severe acute migraines are rizatriptan and eletriptan.

Oral dosage forms of triptans are the most convenient to use. Still, they may not be practical in patients experiencing migraine-associated nausea and vomiting, for whom injectable and nasal spray formulations are helpful.

Standard treatment comprises a 6-mg subcutaneous dose of sumatriptan. All triptans have similar pharmacologic properties but vary slightly in terms of clinical efficacy. Rizatriptan and eletriptan are the most efficacious of the triptans currently available.

The FDA approved celecoxib, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, for the treatment of acute migraine with or without aura in adults. The drug is not indicated for the preventive treatment of migraine.

questions.text: A young woman has been suffering from 1-2 episodes of migraine every week. These episodes are affecting her quality of life. All of the following drugs can be used in the prophylaxis of migraine in this patient except
questions.solution:
Sumatriptan is used in the treatment of an acute attack of migraine not in prophylaxis. It can be given by oral, subcutaneous, intravenous or intranasal routes.

Drugs used in the prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta-blockers- propranolol
  • Calcium channel blocker- flunarizine (verapamil, nimodipine has no role)
  • Antidepressants- amitriptyline, venlafaxine (SSRIs like fluoxetine are not used)
  • Anticonvulsants- valproate, topiramate
  • 5-HT2 antagonist- pizotifen
  • CGRP antagonists - erenumab, framanezumab, galcanezumab, eptinezumab

Other modalities of preventative treatment:

  • Greater occipital nerve block
  • Onabotulinum toxin A
  • Supraorbital transcutaneous stimulation

questions.text: Sumatriptan can be given in which of the following patients diagnosed with migraine?

choices.text: A 42-year-old woman who had taken ergot alkaloids in the past one week
A 34-year-old woman presenting with a positive urine pregnancy test
A 48-year-old man with a history of cerebrovascular disease
A 51-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease

questions.solution:
Taking ergot alkaloids in the past one week is not a contraindication for sumatriptan. However, they shouldn't be given together as doing so could result in excessive blood vessel narrowing.

Ergots constrict arteries and triptans narrow normal heart arteries by up to 20%. For this reason, ergots should not be taken with triptans on the same day. 

Sumatriptan is a 5HT1B/1D receptor agonist used in an acute migraine attack. It is contraindicated in the following conditions:

  • Cerebrovascular disease
  • Coronary artery disease

Option B- Sumatriptan is the safest triptan in pregnancy, but its use is recommended only if the benefits outweigh the risks, and if all first line options do not provide relief.

questions.text: What is the use of MIDAS questionnaire?

choices.text: To help decide treatment of migraine

questions.solution:
The Migraine Disability Assessment Score (MIDAS) questionnaire was put together to help measure the impact of migraine on patients' lives.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the preventive treatment of a patient with chronic migraine?
questions.solution:
Onabotulinum toxin A is used in the preventive treatment of patients with chronic migraine. 

Sumatriptan, ergotamine, and metoclopramide are used in the treatment of an acute attack of migraine.

Drugs used in the prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta-blockers- propranolol
  • Calcium channel blocker- flunarizine (verapamil, nimodipine has no role)
  • Antidepressants- amitriptyline, venlafaxine (SSRIs like fluoxetine are not used)
  • Anticonvulsants- valproate, topiramate
  • 5-HT2 antagonist- pizotifen
  • CGRP antagonists - erenumab, framanezumab, galcanezumab, eptinezumab

Other modalities of preventative treatment:

  • Greater occipital nerve block
  • Onabotulinum toxin A
  • Supraorbital transcutaneous stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia?
questions.solution:
Nummular headache is not a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia. It is characterized by small circumscribed areas of continuous pain on the head.

Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia is characterized by pain along the distribution of trigeminal nerve (unilateral) and cranial autonomic symptoms. This is due to increased parasympathetic flow and decreased sympathetic flow.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed indomethacin for his complaint of headache and he felt relief after taking the drug. Which of the following could be a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal hemicrania could be the likely diagnosis since it responds to indomethacin.

It is characterized by frequent unilateral, severe, short-lasting, and frequent episodes of headache. They have marked autonomic features ipsilateral to the pain.

Indomethacin (25–75 mg t.i.d) can completely suppress attacks of paroxysmal hemicrania. It is also effective in:

  • Hemicrania continuum
  • Primary sexual / exercise headache 
  • Tension-type headache

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is diagnosed to have SUNCT. It can be distinguished from trigeminal neuralgia by the presence of all except:
questions.solution:
Short attacks of stabbing pain are common to both SUNCT and trigeminal neuralgia.

SUNCT has autonomic symptoms such as lacrimation, nasal congestion, conjunctival injection, and salivation. Trigeminal neuralgia does not have autonomic symptoms.

questions.text: All are true about patients with trigeminal neuralgia except:

choices.text: Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve
No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.solution:
Trigeminal neuralgia is associated with superficial pain and not deep-seated pain.

It is more common (~ 60% of cases) in females (Option A) over 50 years and is characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain. This most commonly involves the second and/or third divisions (Option B) of the trigeminal nerve territory. Bilateral or early-onset pain is associated with multiple sclerosis. Unilateral trigeminal nerve compression can be due to the superior cerebellar artery.

Pain is repetitive, severe, and brief and can be triggered by touch, cold, wind, or eating. Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux). No signs of sensory loss are present (Option D)

The drug of choice is carbamazepine.

Note: It is important to note that trigeminal neuralgia and trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (TAC) are different entities. TAC is a group of primary headaches that include - cluster headaches, paroxysmal hemicrania, short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)/short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic symptoms (SUNA), and hemicrania continua.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with an extremely painful headache that came on suddenly without warning. It reached maximum intensity within 1 minute and lasted for 5 minutes. Which of the following would you not include as a differential?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thunderclap headache. Subdural hemorrhage will not produce this type of headache.

Causes of thunderclap headache:

  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Acute hydrocephalus
  • Pituitary apoplexy
  • Cerebral venous thrombosis
  • Hypertensive crisis
